content:
Reduce the amount of bias in your Einstein bot by revising your bot script and intent model. Use accessibility best practices and design by channel to create a great bot experience every time.

When building your Einstein Bot, think about unintentional built-in bias. The more humans building the bot can reduce bias, the stronger the bot experience and the greater likelihood of customer retention. After the launch, review the bot's metrics regularly and revise as needed.

Build bots with your target audience in mind. Fine-tune your bot script by sharing it with stakeholders from your target audience and revising based on their feedback. Learn more about crafting bot conversations.

Build a balanced and diverse intent model for accurate intent recognition. Intent models can introduce bias if the bot moves the conversation with users in unexpected directions. Balance data by including roughly the same number of utterances for each intent, varied across multiple dialects, slang, misspellings, and speech impairments to ensure all audiences are included.

Many template bots come preloaded with balanced intent data for specific intents, but you can source your own through internal crowdsourcing or a survey company. Make sure people generating utterances capture the makeup of your target audience.

Build a bot that considers accessibility and channel specifics. Bots are designed to exist on a specific channel, so building without researching methods can lead to a poor final product. Test bots on the intended channel before deployment and turn on accessibility tools to confirm the bot works for all customers. If deploying to multiple channels, design the bot to fit the most restrictive channel.

Learn more about different types of bias on Trailhead: Recognize Bias in Artificial Intelligence.
title: Reducing Bias in AI Bots
